story:
Once upon a time, in a small village in India, there lived a kind and wise Hindu father named Rajan. Rajan had a young son named Rohan, who was full of curiosity and always eager to learn.

One day, Rohan asked his father, "Baba, why do we worship so many gods and goddesses in Hinduism?"

Rajan thought for a moment and then began to tell Rohan a story.

"Long ago, there was a powerful demon named Mahisha who terrorized the people and the gods," Rajan began. "The gods tried to defeat him, but he was too strong. They knew they needed help, so they turned to the great goddess Durga."

"Durga was a fierce warrior, with many arms and weapons to defend herself. She rode a lion and was adorned with jewelry and garlands. The gods bestowed upon her their own divine powers, making her even stronger," Rajan continued.

"Durga battled Mahisha for days, but he would not fall. Finally, she used her ultimate weapon, a trident, and struck him in the heart. Mahisha was defeated, and the people were finally free from his tyranny."

"But Baba, why do we worship so many other gods and goddesses if Durga is so powerful?" Rohan asked.

"My dear Rohan, Durga is just one of many aspects of the divine. Each god and goddess represents a different quality or energy of the universe. Some bring wealth and prosperity, while others bring knowledge and wisdom. By worshiping them, we are inviting those qualities into our lives," Rajan explained.

"But Rohan, it's important to remember that ultimately, they are all just different facets of the one supreme power that created and sustains the universe. We call that power Brahman."

"Brahman is beyond form and cannot be fully understood or described. But through our worship and devotion, we can connect with that power and find inner peace and enlightenment," Rajan concluded.

Rohan listened intently and then looked up at his father with awe. "Baba, I understand now. Thank you for telling me this story."

Rajan smiled and tucked Rohan into bed. "Good night, my son. May you always remember the power of the divine within you."

And so, Rohan drifted off to sleep, with a newfound understanding of the rich and diverse tradition of Hinduism.

The end.
